item.title: Assignment 1 (solution)
item.description: Problem 1 The code below is written for ease of reading, not efficiency. It can be made more efficient by replace the for loops by matrix multiplication. julia> (X,U,W) = (2,3,3); julia> P = [0.25 0.15 0.05; 0.30 0.10 0.15] 2×3 Array{Float64,2}: 0.25 0.15 0.05 0.3 0.1 0.15 julia> C = zeros(X,U,W); julia> C[:,:,1] = [3 5 1; 2 3 1]; julia> C[:,:,2] = [4 3 1; 1 2 8]; julia> C[:,:,3] = [1 2 2; 4 1 3]; julia> C 2×3×3 Array{Float64,3}: [:, :, 1] = 3.

Assignment 3 (solution)
item.description: Problem 2 We are given that for any \(x, y \in \mathbb N\) \[\begin{equation}\label{eq:1} f(x+1, y+1) - f(x+1, y) \le f(x, y+1) - f(x,y). \end{equation}\] We want to show that the above equation implies that for any \(x,x',y,y' \in \mathbb N\) such that \(x' \ge x\) and \(y' \ge y\), we have \[\begin{equation}\label{eq:final} f(x', y') - f(x', y) \le f(x, y') - f(x,y) \end{equation}\] Let \(n = x' - x\) and \(m = y' - y\).

item.title: Assignment 4 (solution)
item.description: Problem 1 This is an optimal stopping problem. Let \(X_t\) denote the population at time \(t\) and \(U_t \in \{0,1\}\) deote the decision to stop (\(U_t = 0\)) or not (\(U_t = 1\)). If the hunter has not made a stopping decision, the dynamics of \(\{X_t\}_{t \ge 1}\) are given by \[ X_{t+1} = \begin{cases} X_t, & \text{with probability $1 - p(X_t)$} \\ X_t - 1, & \text{with probability $p(X_t)$} \end{cases} \]

item.title: Assignment 5 (solution)
item.description: Let \(X_t\) denote the maximum offer received so far. Then, \[X_t = \max\{W_1, \dots, W_t\}\] and \[X_{t+1} = \max\{ X_t, W_{t+1} \}. \] The above dynamics are monotone; in particular, if \(x > y\) then \[ \max\{x, W\} \ge \max{y, W}. \] The dynamic program for the above model can be written as \[V_{T}(x) = x \] and for \(t \in \{T-1, \dots, 1\}\), \[ V_t(x) = \max\{ x, - c + \max\{x, W\} \}.

item.title: Assignment 7 (solution)
item.description: Part a. Let \(Y_t \in \{0, 1\}\) denote the observation of the player where \(Y_t = 0\) means that the output was a failure and \(Y_t = 1\) means that the output was a success. Let \(I_t = \{Y_{1:t-1}, U_{1:t-1} \}\) denote all the information available to the player. From the definition of \((M_t, N_t)\), the evolution of \((M_t, N_t)\) can be written as \[ (M_{t+1}, N_{t+1}) = \begin{cases} (M_t, N_t), & U_t = A \\ (M_t + 1, N_t), & U_t = B, Y_t = 1 \\ (M_t , N_t + 1), & U_t = B, Y_t = 0 \end{cases}\]
